item.title: M3
item.description: Messier 3 - a 6.4 magnitude globular cluster in the constellation Canes Venatici. Taken with the Canon T5i on the 80 mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description: Messier 3 - a 6.4 magnitude globular cluster in the constellation Canes Venatici. Taken with the Canon T5i on the 80 mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M5
item.description:
Globular cluster M5 showing full frame.
Atik 383L CCD, R-filter, through the 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
Globular cluster M5 showing full frame.
Atik 383L CCD, R-filter, through the 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M5
item.description:
M5, globular cluster in Serpens. The red color pallette is for fun and does not give accurate colors, although the stars in globular clusters are truly old and contain no O or B blue stars.
Atik 383L CCD on the Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
M5, globular cluster in Serpens. The red color pallette is for fun and does not give accurate colors, although the stars in globular clusters are truly old and contain no O or B blue stars.
Atik 383L CCD on the Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: Messier 13 - globular cluster.
item.description: Messier 13, a globular cluster in the keystone of Hercules. One of the brightest of the globular clusters that orbit our Galaxy. Taken with R, G, and B filters using the Atik CCD on the apochromatic refractor in 2015 and cropped down.
item.media:description: Messier 13, a globular cluster in the keystone of Hercules. One of the brightest of the globular clusters that orbit our Galaxy. Taken with R, G, and B filters using the Atik CCD on the apochromatic refractor in 2015 and cropped down.

item.title: Messier 38
item.description: Messier 38, aka the Starfish Cluster, is an open cluster in Auriga. The small concentration of stars at the bottom is probably NGC 1907.
item.media:description: Messier 38, aka the Starfish Cluster, is an open cluster in Auriga. The small concentration of stars at the bottom is probably NGC 1907.

item.title: M44 - the Praesepe
item.description: M44, the Praesepe star cluster in Cancer. A very nearby cluster (600 LY) requiring a wide field of view to capture. This was taken with the Canon T5i on the 80 mm apo refractor.
item.media:description: M44, the Praesepe star cluster in Cancer. A very nearby cluster (600 LY) requiring a wide field of view to capture. This was taken with the Canon T5i on the 80 mm apo refractor.

item.title: M44 - Praesepe
item.description:
M44, also known as the Praesepe or the Beehive Cluster, located in Cancer.
Taken with an Atik 343L CCD and an 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
M44, also known as the Praesepe or the Beehive Cluster, located in Cancer.
Taken with an Atik 343L CCD and an 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M45- The Pleiades
item.description: M45, also known as the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters, is one of the nearest open clusters to Earth. Composed of a grouping of hot young blue stars and their associated reflection nebula, the Pleiades are easily visible to the naked eye near the constellation Taurus, even from light-polluted skies. Taken with Atik 383L CCD and Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. The colors are not quite accurate although the nebulosity is blue.
item.media:description: M45, also known as the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters, is one of the nearest open clusters to Earth. Composed of a grouping of hot young blue stars and their associated reflection nebula, the Pleiades are easily visible to the naked eye near the constellation Taurus, even from light-polluted skies. Taken with Atik 383L CCD and Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. The colors are not quite accurate although the nebulosity is blue.

item.title: M45 the Pleiades star cluster.
item.description: M45 the Pleiades star cluster in Taurus. Rotated so that North is up. The blue reflection nebula is barely visible, especially below the bright star just below center. Canon T5i on the Meade 80 mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description: M45 the Pleiades star cluster in Taurus. Rotated so that North is up. The blue reflection nebula is barely visible, especially below the bright star just below center. Canon T5i on the Meade 80 mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M45- The Pleiades
item.description: M45, the Pleiades star cluster in Taurus. Also known as the Seven Sisters because about seven of the stars are visible to most people's unaided eye. This is a relatively young star cluster which is moving through dust to create a reflection nebula (barely visible here). Atik CCD on 80 mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description: M45, the Pleiades star cluster in Taurus. Also known as the Seven Sisters because about seven of the stars are visible to most people's unaided eye. This is a relatively young star cluster which is moving through dust to create a reflection nebula (barely visible here). Atik CCD on 80 mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: M67 star cluster
item.description: M67 is one of the oldest known open star clusters. Most open clusters are much less than 1 billion years old, but this one is about 3-5 billion years old. It is fairly close, at 2700 LY.
item.media:description: M67 is one of the oldest known open star clusters. Most open clusters are much less than 1 billion years old, but this one is about 3-5 billion years old. It is fairly close, at 2700 LY.

item.title: M67 - old star cluster.
item.description: Messier 67, an open star cluster in the constellation Cancer. It's age is estimated to be 4 billion years whereas most open clusters are much less than 1 billion years old. Stars clusters disperse over time so this one was probably once much richer. Taken with the SVbony guide camera.
item.media:description: Messier 67, an open star cluster in the constellation Cancer. It's age is estimated to be 4 billion years whereas most open clusters are much less than 1 billion years old. Stars clusters disperse over time so this one was probably once much richer. Taken with the SVbony guide camera.

item.title: M103 in Cassiopeia
item.description: Messier 103, an open cluster in Cassiopeia. Slightly out of focus image taken with the Atik CCD on the Celestron C11. N is up.
item.media:description: Messier 103, an open cluster in Cassiopeia. Slightly out of focus image taken with the Atik CCD on the Celestron C11. N is up.

item.title: Double Cluster in Perseus
item.description: The Double Cluster (NGC 884 and 869) in Perseus. These open clusters are visible to the naked eye (under good sky conditions) just above the peak of the head of Perseus. Atik CCD through RGB filters taken on the 80 mm apo refractor. Rotated so that N is up.
item.media:description: The Double Cluster (NGC 884 and 869) in Perseus. These open clusters are visible to the naked eye (under good sky conditions) just above the peak of the head of Perseus. Atik CCD through RGB filters taken on the 80 mm apo refractor. Rotated so that N is up.

item.title: Double Cluster in Perseus.
item.description: The Double Cluster (NGC 884 and 869) in Perseus. These open clusters are visible to the naked eye (under good sky conditions) just above the peak of the head of Perseus. Atik CCD through RGB filters taken on the 80 mm apo refractor. Rotated so that N is up.
item.media:description: The Double Cluster (NGC 884 and 869) in Perseus. These open clusters are visible to the naked eye (under good sky conditions) just above the peak of the head of Perseus. Atik CCD through RGB filters taken on the 80 mm apo refractor. Rotated so that N is up.

item.title: Double Cluster in Perseus.
item.description: The Double Cluster, or NGC 869 and NGC 844, are a pair of open clusters in the constellation Perseus. DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. N is up.
item.media:description: The Double Cluster, or NGC 869 and NGC 844, are a pair of open clusters in the constellation Perseus. DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. N is up.

item.title: NGC 884
item.description: NGC 884, eastern half of the Double Cluster in Perseus. N is up. DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description: NGC 884, eastern half of the Double Cluster in Perseus. N is up. DSI II CCD, Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: NGC 1502 - young cluster
item.description: NGC 1502 is special in that it is a very young cluster with an age of about 5 million years. It contains only about 60 stars. Canon T5i on the 80mm apo.
item.media:description: NGC 1502 is special in that it is a very young cluster with an age of about 5 million years. It contains only about 60 stars. Canon T5i on the 80mm apo.

item.title: NGC 2395
item.description: NGC 2395 - a star cluster in Gemini. Taken with the SVbony 305 guide camera.
item.media:description: NGC 2395 - a star cluster in Gemini. Taken with the SVbony 305 guide camera.

item.title: NGC 2419 in B&W
item.description: NGC 2419 in black and white. The most distant globular cluster orbitting our Milky Way. Wide field view showing NGC 2424, a distant galaxy, in the top left background. N is up. Atik CCD on the 80 mm apo refractor.
item.media:description: NGC 2419 in black and white. The most distant globular cluster orbitting our Milky Way. Wide field view showing NGC 2424, a distant galaxy, in the top left background. N is up. Atik CCD on the 80 mm apo refractor.

item.title: NGC 2419 - distant globular cluster
item.description: NGC 2419 is the most distant globular cluster bound to our Milky Way galaxy. Atik CCD with RGB filters on the Celestron C11. N is up and E to left.
item.media:description: NGC 2419 is the most distant globular cluster bound to our Milky Way galaxy. Atik CCD with RGB filters on the Celestron C11. N is up and E to left.

item.title: IC 1848
item.description: IC 1848 - a star cluster with nebulosity (not visible) in Cassiopeia. This was a 144 sec exposure with the Canon T5i through the 11-inch Celestron.
item.media:description: IC 1848 - a star cluster with nebulosity (not visible) in Cassiopeia. This was a 144 sec exposure with the Canon T5i through the 11-inch Celestron.
